resource.chars:
21   It is a fact of much importance in the due appreciation of the
relations of <u>Orbitolite</u> and its allied forms to other tribes of Foraminifera,
that the calcareous partition which separates each cell of any one zone from its
neighbours on either side, is not double, but <u>single</u>. And this is in great part the
case, even with regard to the partitions that separate the cells of successive
zones; the inner or central boundary of one being chiefly formed by the
peripheral wall of the other. It is not easy even in thin <u>sections</u> to distinguish
the boundary between the walls of one zone and those of another; so absolutely
continuous do they appear to be. But it not infrequently happens, that
in <u>fracturing</u> these disks, their component zones come apart from each 
other, along their natural lines of junction, so as to disclose the real
inner (or central) margin of the outer segment (Plate II Fig 6), which
then presents a set of wide apertures, through which we look at once into its
cells; thus proving their incomplete inclosure by proper walls on that
side. Thus in the formation of each new zone, the calcareous envelope
seems to be only generated where the sarcode is not already <s>protected by</s> in contact with a
solid wall.

22. There cannot be nay reasonable doubt, that the number of concentric
zones which any disk may present, is entirely determined by the stage of
